title: 107_hr970
content: SECTION 1. SAFE AND DRUG-FREE SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES. Part A of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and additional funds for the following 4 years to implement subpart 2. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and additional funds for the following 4 years to implement subpart 2. This includes redesignating sections and inserting new sections as specified. SEC. 4121. COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Secretary is authorized to provide grants to States to implement prevention programs meeting high scientific standards. States must submit a plan detailing the process for awarding grants to local educational agencies and ensuring program quality. The educational agency will provide competitive grants to eligible local educational agencies to fund high-quality prevention programs. The State educational agency will ensure the dissemination of research-based prevention models and provide technical assistance to help local educational agencies in implementing these programs. The State educational agency will provide technical assistance to local educational agencies in evaluating, selecting, developing, and implementing prevention programs. They will also evaluate the implementation of these programs and measure the results achieved in preventing various problem behaviors and improving student academic performance. Additionally, the agency will ensure that local programs meet specific requirements. The State educational agency will ensure that local programs meet specific requirements, including preventing delinquent behavior, substance abuse, and improving academic performance. Funds provided under this subpart must supplement, not supplant, other available funds. Other criteria may be required by the Secretary. "SEC. 4122. RESERVATIONS AND ALLOCATIONS." The Secretary reserves and allocates funds for this subpart, with specific guidelines for reservations and reallocation of funds to States that do not meet plan requirements. The Secretary reserves and allocates funds for this subpart, with guidelines for reallocation of funds to States that do not meet plan requirements. If a State agency fails to develop a compliant plan, funds will be reallocated to other States that have met the requirements, and can only be used for program implementation. "SEC. 4123. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS." Each State educational agency receiving funds under section 4004(2) must provide competitive grants to local educational agencies based on demonstrated need. Grant awards should prioritize agencies with the greatest need and be of sufficient size. The State educational agency must provide grants to local educational agencies based on need, prioritizing those with the greatest need. Grants should support startup costs for a prevention plan and consider equitable distribution across different regions and school types. The State educational agency must distribute grants based on need, prioritizing those with the greatest need and considering equitable distribution across different regions and school types. Up to 5 percent of funds can be used for administrative expenses and informing local educational agencies about effective prevention approaches. "SEC. 4124. LOCAL AWARDS." To be eligible for a subgrant, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The agency must also submit a plan demonstrating how it will meet program requirements and use funds for prevention programs. A grant awarded to a local educational agency must be used for implementing prevention programs that are research-based, address various aspects of children's health, and include developmentally appropriate activities. The grant awarded to a local educational agency must implement prevention programs that comprehensively address the mental, emotional, social, and physical health of children and adolescents, employ developmentally appropriate activities and interventions, assist in improving cognitive, affective, and behavioral skills, ensure active engagement of participants, and involve parents, educators, and health professionals. The prevention programs funded by the grant must involve children and adolescents, improve communication between children and adults, involve parents, educators, and health professionals, provide staff training, set measurable goals, and utilize external technical support. The prevention programs funded by the grant must have measurable outcome goals, a clear evaluation plan, use external technical support, and coordinate resources from various sources to support the comprehensive prevention effort.
